doc.field: 3800 victims of earthquake in Turkey, amongst them some Germans

The number of victims killed by the earthquake in Turkey continues to rise. So far, authorities have counted 3800 dead and almost 18'000 injured. Three Germans are among the dead. Six other Germans are still being missed. Meanwhile, more than 1000 helpers from 19 countries work in the disaster area. The German Forces has also offered Turkey its support. The largest Turkish refinery in Ismit is still in flames. Specialists try to use water bombers from Germany and three other countries to control the fire.
Drug industry rejects agreement on medicament budget

Last night's agreement between Federal Health Minister Angelika Fischer and registered physicians about the drug budget for the current year has been partially met with criticism. Representatives of the pharma industry stated that the industry expects profit losses worth billions of marks. The physicians said they still wanted to do away with budgeting. Union and FDP politicians were also opposed to the agreement. One item of the agreement is that more generic products be prescribed to stay within the budget.
Hospitals demand withdrawal of planned health reform

Representatives of hospitals have called on the German government to withdraw the health reform to be introduced on January 1, 2000. After a meeting with Health Minister Angelika Fischer the president of the German Hospital Society, Mr. Pfoehler, said in Bonn that the hospitals were overburdened. The government had no solutions for the existential problems of the hospitals.
Unions threaten with consequences if shopping hours are extended

The Alliance for Employment might suffer if the shopping hours are extended. The union for retail, banking, and insurance HBV threatened the government with more conflicts within the Alliance for Employment if the shopping hours law were relaxed. In a preemptive move, the union for employees in North Rhine-Westphalia, DAG, has given notice of termination of the collective agreement. By doing this, the union wants to make sure that if the shopping hours are extended the wages can also be raised.
KaDeWe remains closed next Sunday
The largest and most famous department store in Germany, the KaDeWe in Berlin will remain closed next Sunday. The store's workers council rejected an application for one additional opening on Sunday.
Shareholders of IG Farben decide compensation for forced labourers

Former forced labourers of IG Farben will be compensated with 3 million marks from a foundation. This was decided today at the stockholders meeting in Frankfurt on Main. 92.5 percent of the shareholders of the assign of IG Farben Industrie AG in liquidation voted for the motion of the liquidators. The money will be taken from the company's assets. Representatives of the Critical Shareholders and of NS victim associations, however, demanded a quick liquidation of the company and to pay the full remaining assets of 21 million DM to the victims.
Hombach now also criticized by his own party

Former Secretary of the Chancellor's Office Bodo Hombach is now also criticized by his own party for his role in the latest real estate affaire. The president of the North Rhine-Westphalian SPD, Franz Muentefering, said it was pivotal that Hombach had allowed himself in the 80s when he was chief executive officer of the NRW-SPD to co-operate privately with one of the largest contractors of the party. The current-affairs magazine Stern had reported yesterday about construction project in Canada in which Hombach's mother had a share and, indirectly, an advertiser who had received honorariums of millions of marks for ad campaigns for the NRW-SPD.
Budget cuts for Deutsche Welle unavoidable

The government sticks to the budget cuts for Deutsche Well, Germany's international radio station. Today, government spokesman Heye called on the station to make constructive suggestions. Heye said, one option was closer collaboration with the public broadcasters ARD and ZDF. He could not follow statements by Deutsche Welle president Weyrich that the budget cuts would result in 745 lost jobs.
German re-approved for meetings of EU ministers

The quarrel between Finland and Germany about language use within the EU administration has been resolved. German may be used again when EU ministers meet. For weeks, Finland had insisted on the EU's unwritten law that only English, French and the presiding country's language may be used at informal minister meetings. Finland is currently presiding over the EU.
Sewage sludge scandal now also in Bavaria
One week after the sewage sludge scandal in France a similar case has surfaced in Bavaria. A factory in Platling has turned sludge into animal food for years with the approval of the authorities.
